div.p: 1. IV. Sunday.

Thick fog this morning and afterwards a South wind, as predicted last Evening by Edward Miller— Heard P. Whitney in the morning from Romans 12.1. “I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.” The Sermon was an earnest exhortation to the members of the Congregation, to join in Communion with the Church— And the communion was administered— Louisa C Smith dined with us— The afternoon discourse was from Luke 10.38. [“]Now it came to pass, as they went, that he entered into a certain village; and a certain woman, named Martha received him into her house. 39. And she had a sister, called Mary, which also Sat at Jesus’ feet, and heard his word. 40. But Martha was cumbered about much serving, and came to him and said, Lord, dost thou not care that my Sister hath left me to serve alone? bid her therefore that she help me. 41. And Jesus answered, and said unto her, Martha, Martha, thou art careful and troubled about many things: 42. But one thing is needful: and Mary hath chosen that good part which shall not be taken away from her.” This as Mr Whitney observed is a very instructive narration; and pointedly marks a preference of religious and intellectual pursuit, even to the obligations of hospitality— It is a profoundly moral lesson, and contains one of the principal characteristics of the Christian religion— After the Evening service, I was reading to my wife part of a chapter of Butler’s analogy, when General Dearborn and Mr Degrand came in, and spent the Evening here— I began this morning the Philosophical works of Cicero with the Treatise de finibus bonorum et malorum—This work I have never read— It contains the exposition of the principles of the three great sects of the Grecian Philosophy— The Epicurean, the Stoic, and the peripatetic— It is in five books, addressed to Marcus Brutus, in return for one, by Brutus addressed to him upon Virtue— The first book is a dialogue between Lucius Torquatus, Caius Triarius, and Cicero himself, at his Cumanum, or villa at Cumae, where they were visiting him— I read 11. Sections of the first Book, and then read an English Translation of the same, which I find among the books of my father’s Library; called Tully’s five Books de finibus, or concerning the last Object of Desire and Aversion. Done into English by S. P. Gent—revised and compared with the Original, with a recommendatory Preface by Jeremy Collier, M.A. together with an Apology for the philosophical writings of Cicero, in a letter to the Translator, by Mr Henry Dodwell: published by Jacob Tonson in 1702— S. P. was Parker— The names of Collier and Dodwell are eminent in English Literature.
2. IV:20. Monday.

Mr Bass came and paid a year’s interest on his note to me— I agreed to postpone the payment of the first instalment of the principal, till the next year— He spoke of paying the whole of the principal, by borrowing of some other person; and said Mr Curtis told him he could borrow money to any amount, at five per Cent interest, giving security— I promised to deliver up his note and to discharge the mortgage at any day when it might suit his convenience to make the payment— I planted a row of 24 crushed Whortleberries, along by the western Wall of my Nursery— Filled 3 book boxes with Earth, and stationed them in the garden, near the gate of my Nursery—for promiscuous experiments—to pass the winter sub dio. Planted two balsam pear seeds, in my two small green boxes. Bath with R. C. Buchanan. Swam— The Rev Jonathan Homer of Newton called to see me this afternoon— He has been some time engaged upon a history of the English Translations of the Bible, from that of John Wicliff in 1380 to that of
James the first’s divines in 1611. He is brother in law to Dr James Freeman, still Pastor of the Chapel Church in Boston— Mr Homer left with me a printed notice of this work, extracted from the Boston daily Commercial Gazette. In the Evening I rode with Mary to the beach below Mount Wollaston. Finished reading the first Book of Cicero de Finibus, and afterwards read Parker’s English translation of it. The introduction is an apology by Cicero for writing upon these philosophical subjects; whence it appears that there were many of his cotemporaries, who blamed him for this employment of part of his time— They thought there was no use in meddling with the philosophy of the Greeks—and they maintained even that the Latin language was not suitable for philosophical disquisition. Cicero maintains on the contrary that the Latin language is richer than the Greek— There was indeed no moral philosophy at Rome before Cicero— Their young men were sent for Instruction to Athens; and there were taught the Grecian Philosophy— They adopted according to their individual characters, one or other of the systems of the Grecian Schools, and some were Epicureans, some Stoics, and some peripatetics, or Academics— There was no Original Roman philosophy; Lucretius was a cotemporary of Cicero, and his Poem was an exposition of the Epicurean System, in beautiful verse. Torquatus in this dialogue, delivers it in elegant prose—and he gives very plausible answers to the common objections against the System. The Style, as that of all Cicero’s writings is flowing and easy—adapted to the subject; between the undress of the familiar Epistles, and the formal array of the Orations.
3. IV. Tuesday.

I went to Boston with John Kirke in the Chaise; and immediately to my Son Charles’s Office— My brothers eldest Son, Thomas Boylston Adams, was of age this day, and in the settlement of my father’s Estate, I had contracted to pay him this day 3000 dollars for my father’s devise to him— I deposited that sum to his credit in the United States Branch Bank at Boston; and took the certificate of that fact from the Cashier; which I immediately enclosed in a Letter to the Lieutenant, who is stationed at Fort Moultrie, on Sullivan’s Island, near Charleston, South-Carolina— I made some acquisitions of hard-ware at C. Brooks’s shop, and called at Doggett’s, and saw the full-length portrait of me, the head of which was painted by Stuart, and the body by Sully; which Mr W. N. Boylston gave to the University at Cambridge. Returning to Charles’s Office, I met there Mr Nathl Curtis, to whom I gave the deed of the Executors of W. N. Boylston to Gideon Snow, executed and acknowledged by me. Mr DeGrand called also, while I was there. At one, we left Charles’s Office in the midst of a shower which, soon subsided, and returned to Quincy to dine. Abigail S. and Elizabeth C. Adams, were there, and dined with us. Visited my garden after dinner. Planted a row of Lime seeds along by that of whortleberries planted yesterday in the Nursery: but all those Limeseeds float in the Water, and I do not expect will ever come up— Planted also rows of cherries, stones, and whortleberries in the Southern book-box; and one thimbleberry whole in the centre of the box. The seeds of these small fruits when fresh from the berry sink in water— I was unwell with the usual oppression upon the Lungs— Read this morning 12 Sections of the second Book de Finibus, and Parker’s English Translation— In this Book Cicero himself states his objections to the Epicurean system of philosophy. I began also the fourth Volume of the English Calmet.
4. IV:15 Wednesday.

The annoyance of Wasps, flies, black ants, Squash bugs, Turnep worms, and insects numberless, is inseparable from the interest and pleasure of plantation. The gourd and the worm of Jonah, are descriptive of natural phenomena and human passions operative alike in all ages— Every plant that I raise from the seed takes hold of my affections; and when it perishes by a stroke of the Sun, or winter’s frost, or a voracious insect, I feel a disappointed hope— As the nutmeg peaches ripen, wasps and flies fasten upon them: the decay of rottenness immediately commences; and the wasps and flies eat the ripening side in to the Stone. I found this morning, in that condition, all those which had yesterday the appearance of immediate ripening. I plucked and planted a row of them in the middle book-box—and several old Horse-chesnuts by the limeseeds and whortle berries in the Nursery. Swam from wharf to wharf. An old clergyman by the name of Daniel Oliver and disposed of the works of the Revd. Samuel Shaw; of which he has published, an Edition in two Volumes 12mo. all but 80 copies of which were consumed by fire in April 1825. Mr Oliver is a minister dismissed, and preaches wherever he finds an opportunity. I read 12 Sections of the second Book de Finibus, and to Mrs Adams part of a Chapter of Butler’s Analogy.
5. IV:40. Thursday.

Gathered white currants, for the experiment both of raising them from the seed and if they come up of ascertaining if the fruit will be of the same kind— Swim at Noon. Lieutenant Buchanan went with me to the wharf, but not into the bath— Letters to Cumberland D. Williams and Dr. B. Waterhouse— Settled monthly accounts. In the afternoon Mr James H. Foster, his wife, and daughters Elizabeth and Louisa paid us a short visit— John and the Lieutt. rode, towards the blue-hills— Evening ride with my wife and daughter. Brought home some Stalks of the Podalyria Tinctoria or wild indigo, which I examined—by Dr Bigelow’s Florula Bostoniensis— It is now just in blossom. He refers for its Medical properties to Thacher’s Dispensatory— I finished reading the second Book de Finibus in which Cicero sets forth in full detail his objections to the Epicurean System of Philosophy. This enquiry after the summum bonum, or the end of human existence, was pursued with great ardour by the Grecian Philosophers—different minds came to different conclusions— But these conclusions were all speculative—they had no sanction of superior authority— Their operation upon human conduct was therefore imperfect. Epicurus taught that the supreme good was sensual pleasure—and that all evil resolved itself into pain— There were however two other varieties of the Epicurean philosophy—one which considered the absence of pain the supreme good—and the other, durable or permanent pleasure. Zeno placed the Supreme good in Virtue, and this was the foundation of the Stoic Philosophy— The Academick, and Peripatetic Schools, of Plato and Aristotle, formed a middle term between the rigorous doctrines of Zeno, and the laxity of Epicurus— They considered Virtue as the Supreme good; but that the external advantages of Fortune were also good; and that Virtue was not of itself all sufficient for human happiness. The demonstration against the Doctrine of Epicurus in this book is complete— The end of human existence is not enjoyment, but action. The mischief of the Epicurean theory was not so much in itself, as in the influence which it exercised over human action— He guarded it partially, by teaching that the highest and only perfect
enjoyment consisted in the practice of virtue, and Torquatus boasts that Epicurus himself was eminently virtuous both in life and death— Cicero gives a Letter from Epicurus written on the day of his death to Hermachus, written under the agony of the Stone, in which he declares himself though suffering the extremity of the Stone, still happy in the remembrance of his great discoveries—and recommends to his friend to take care of the children of Metrodorus: and Cicero remarks the utter inconsistency of this Letter with the principles of its author— The tendency of Epicureanism has always been to the corruption of morals; nor have any of his disciples in any age been remarkable for their virtue—
6. III.30. Friday.

The night being clear, I rose this morning before daylight to see if I could discern the rising of Sirius; but he is yet too near the Sun— I planted in the middle book-box a cross row of 12 white Currants— Bigelow marks two varieties of the Blackberry Rubus Villosus, and Rubus Frondosus, one of which he calls the Tall blackberry and the other the Leafy Raspberry, which he says have been confounded together. I have one of them at the corner of my garden but know not which it is— I shall mark its growth— Swam between noon and one with Lieutt. R. C. Buchanan— Tide unusually high. My brother and his family with Ann Harrod, and Louisa C. Smith dined with us. I rode home with my brothers wife and Louisa Smith— I gave my brother the copy of the Record, of the Lots set off to me, about ten Acres of woodland in the 600 Acres from my fathers Estate, by order of the Court of Common Pleas Norfolk County— The acceptance by the Court of the Report of the Commissioners, is not entered upon the record, which I thought left it imperfect— My brother agreed to go with me to Dedham next Monday— The acceptance must first be entered on the Records of the Court— Then copied by the Register of Deeds, on his Record; and then entered upon my copy; which is the quasi-deed, and my voucher of title— I read twelve Sections of the third book of de Finibus— This is a different dialogue from that of the two first Books— The interlocutors now, are Cicero and Cato of Utica, who are represented as meeting accidentally at a Cuman villa belonging to a boy named Lucullus, whose father had left him a large Library, and of whom Cato was the Guardian. Cicero goes there upon a day when theatrical games are exhibited at Rome—to look up some Treatises of Aristotle which he wished to consult: and meets there Cato surrounded by volumes of the Stoic writers— This naturally introduces a Conversation upon the Stoic doctrines, which at the request of Cicero, Cato fully sets forth— He begins by expressing an earnest wish that Cicero would adopt those doctrines, telling him with a flattering compliment, that he above all other men should maintain that Virtue is the only good. Cicero insists that the difference between the Peripatetics and Stoics was merely on words; Cato undertakes to shew great and essential differences between them.
7. III.30. Saturday.

Rose again by Candle light, but the morning was cloudy—and there was no opportunity for watching the first appearance of the Dog-Star— With my Son John and Lieutenant Buchanan I went and dined with Mr Peter C. Brooks at Medford— We stopped at Charles’s Office in Court Street, where John alighted and went thence with his brother. We proceeded to the Navy-Yard at Charlestown, where I visited Commodore Morris but he was not at home— We went nevertheless into the Navy-yard where the Superintendant Mrmet us and accompanied us on board the Columbus, line of Battle ship; which has been
lying in Ordinary here nearly ten years— Here we saw Captain Abbott with his wife, and two children, who have a comfortable residence in the Cabin of the ship— I enquired for Coll. Baldwin, but he was gone to dinner. Saw the state of the works which have made some progress since I saw them two years ago. Robert enquired for Midshipman Lincoln; the Governor’s Son, who came and accompanied us to the Bunker-Hill Monument, which is now like the adventure of the Bear and Fiddle— We went up inside as high as it is completed; and whence there is a beautiful view of the Town the City and the Bay— We proceeded to Medford which we reached some time before Mr Brooks came in from Boston. Mrs Frothingham, and her children are there for the Summer. Charles’s wife has been there this fortnight. Mr Frothingham, and Mr and Mrs Edward Everett were there at dinner— Mrs Brooks is no longer there—but I hope in a happier world.— I felt painfully her absence; recollecting her kindness whenever I had been there before— After dinner we walked over the grounds, which I had often seen before; excepting four or five shell-bark trees in full bearing; one of which is over a century old— I asked for a quart of Acorns from his large white Oak, if they should come to maturity. We returned through Boston to Quincy in the Evening. This morning I finished reading the third Book de Finibus. The principles of the Stoic Philosophy were sublime. But it may be doubted whether Cicero, though speaking in the name of Cato has altogether fairly set them forth. There is a leaning to the ridiculous even in this statement of the case. Cato acknowledges that there is some obscurity in the language used by the Stoics; and complains that he has no suitable words to render many Greek expressions which they employed— They made very nice discriminations, and used some captious Syllogisms. There is more of enthusiasm than of philosophy in Cato’s preference of this sect— But it is was a doctrine eminently conducive to the dignity of human nature— And it was the doctrine of Cato and Marcus Brutus, the two men of their age the most virtuous.
8. IV.15. Sunday.

I planted the 8. Apricot stones given me yesterday by A. B. Adams—one in the centre of each of my five boxes— One under the Western Wall, and two, with a nutmeg peach between them under the South fence, by the gate— Heard a young man by the name of Fox in the forenoon from Galatians 6.7. [“]Be not deceived; God is not mocked; for whatsoever a man soweth that shall he also reap. 8. For he that soweth to his flesh, shall of the flesh reap corruption: but he that soweth to the Spirit, shall of the Spirit reap life everlasting.” I thought involuntarily of my plantations of the afternoon Sermon, I failed to retain even the text. Yet both the Discourses were ambitiously written, and Mr Fox is a young man of promising talents— He is a student at the theological seminary, in Cambridge— After the second Service I bathed at the wharf with John— Tide low— Robert C. Buchanan and Mary were both much indisposed the whole day— I rode towards Sunset with Mrs Adams and Lieutt. Buchanan to the Mount Wollaston Beach. My brother and G. W. Beale were here in the Evening. Light thunder-shower— I read part of Barrow’s Sermon upon the duty and reward of bounty to the poor. It is in 76 pages of small print, and could not be distinctly read in less than three hours— Rather a dissertation than a Sermon— I also began this morning the fourth Book de Finibus—containing the answer of Cicero to the exposition by Cato of the Stoic system of moral philosophy— His argument is that the foundations of moral philosophy, and the true nature of the Supreme good, had been sufficiently traced and expounded by Plato and Aristotle, and their Successors of the Academic and Peripatetic Schools. That
they had explored every department of Science, and that Zeno who had been a disciple of the Peripatetic Polemo, seceded from his Doctrine, and affected to found a separate school, merely from vanity, and without any real improvement of the System. He complains that the Stoics by the singularity of their language, and uncouth novelties of expression, had debased the Art of Speaking, and says that Cleanthes and Chrysippus had written upon Rhetoric, excellent works for a dumb man to read— The Academic school he says divided the nature of man into body and Soul, attributing to each its appropriate virtues, and giving to the Soul a high pre-eminence over the body— But the principles of the Stoics were suitable only for a being consisting only of a Soul, and without body— As those of the Epicureans were for a mere body without a Soul.
9. IV:45. Monday.— To Dedham and back

My brother came this morning shortly after . . . O’Clock and went with me to Dedham— We called at the Offices of Jairus Ware, Clerk of the Court of Common Pleas, and of Enos Foord, the Register of Deeds. Mr Ware, entered upon his record the acceptance by the Court of the Report of the Commissioners, appointed to set off the ten Acres of Woodland from my father’s Estate, as conveyed by his Deed of Septr. 1819. and annexed to my copy of the proceedings, a certificate of that entry— The register then entered a copy of this Certificate of Mr Ware, in the margin of his Registry, and certified his entry upon my voucher— In this manner the irregularity of the records and voucher was rectified; but this occurrence exemplifies the exceeding caution with which all business relating to the conveyance of real Estate must be managed. I received from Mr Foord the Mortgage of Benjamin Bass to me which has been at the Register’s Office, since July of last year— We returned to Quincy to dine, taking the right hand after crossing Paul’s bridge, and going round by the foot of the highest blue hill— We received visits after dinner, from Mr. Gardner Greene, his wife and daughter, with Mr John Connell of Philadelphia. Dr Parkman with three Ladies of his family; a Mr Jackson Alabama, and Mr Samuel Lewis of Cincinnati Ohio, formerly of this State, from whom I had just before received a Letter upon a project for a high School at Cincinnati— John rode out towards Evening with his mother and wife— Evening dispirited— I finished reading this morning the fourth Book of Cicero de Finibus— This is a partial exposition by Cicero, of the moral philosophy of the Academic and Peripatetic Schools—with the view only to refute that of the Stoics— His objections to the Doctrines of Zeno are, that so far as they are good, they were taken from Plato and Aristotle, and their followers: and that whatever of new there is, in them is either useless, trivial or absurd— He tells Cato that he will not now handle the subject with him as he did, in the defence of Muraena, when he had adapted his discourse to the multitude, attending at the trial, and said much to please the crowd; but he insists that the Stoic denial that pain is an evil is absurd, and their subterfuges, admitting that health, and riches, and honours and power, and in short all comforts other than virtue are desirables or preferables, and the reverse of them rejectables, though neither good nor evil, are ridiculous— Cato intimates that all these objections, are merely popular and not philosophical— Says he will take some other day to reply to them all, as he is able to do, and then after a courteous interchange of compliments the dialogue closes.
10. IV:15. Tuesday.

I attended at French’s Tavern the probate Court now held by Sherman Leland the present Judge— Edward Hutchinson Robbins the late judge died in the course of the last Winter. I enquired for the account which I had filed last November; but judge Robbins had passed no order upon it, and as there was a charge left in Blank, of compensation to the Executors, he said he had established a rule that before allowing such an account notice must be given to all persons interested in the Estate— After some conversation and enquiries he advised me to withdraw the Account presented by me last November, to add to it all the charges which have since occurred, and present it again— I accordingly took it back; and a copy of the Supplementary Inventory, returned last November— The judge gave me also a printed copy of a Rule established by himself of compensation to be allowed to Executors, Administrators and Trustees; and proposed that I should make the charge conformably to it, though he did not intend it as positively applicable to past cases— I told him I should be satisfied to conform to the rule, and to give notice to all the parties interested. I was desirous however of having the Settlement of the Estate as soon completed as possible— After dinner I took a bath, and swam from wharf to wharf alone. The Ladies and John took a ride to Dorchester. I began the fifth Book de Finibus, and was twice in the Garden.— In the morning trimmed a young Elm tree, and found one just up from the seed— My willow stem in the Summerhouse cellar is 26 inches long, and continues growing half an inch a day— The Shellbarks in the cellar appear to be dying. The ground is too low and damp for them— My English Oak, one plum tree in the cellar, and four or five of the Apple trees from the seed of last Summer, have taken a second start of growth and put forth new stem shoots within the last three weeks— The Chesnut, Red and Washington Oaks stopped growing about the 1st. of July, and will put forth no more leaves this year. The horse-chesnuts formed a terminal stem-bud from which the perpendicular shoot will open next Spring— I plucked the three last nutmeg peaches— After dinner I planted along the Eastern fence a row of Lime seeds, woodhouse apple seeds, white currants, and blackberries, multiplying the plantations in the hope that some of them will come up, and wishing to ascertain if the seed will bear its kind.
11. IV:15. Wednesday.

George Hardwick, who now rents the house which Samuel Curtis has hitherto hired came this morning to ask me to make repairs on the house— I asked him if he wished to take it another year— He said he wished to take it for he did not know how long; if repairs were made and the rent reduced. I told him I should not reduce the Rent; nor allow for repairs unless he concluded to remain in the house: but that I would come, and look at the place, and see what he wishes to have done. Mrs Mary Dawes, daughter of Mr John Greenleaf, and Miss Anna Thaxter of Hingham paid us a visit in the afternoon— I rode with the Ladies in the Evening to Braintree, and employed great part of the leisure of the day, in looking up papers relating to the Execution of my father’s Will, some of which I did not find— I planted a row of white currants, blackberries and whortleberries under the South-fence of my Nursery, at the left hand of the gate upon entering— This is under the shade of the fence, and of an Apple-tree standing there; but I have little expectation of any of them coming up—discharged Jane Boden; yesterday.
12. IV. Thursday.

I had invited Dr Waterhouse to dine with me, and he came before Noon— Mr William Plumer junr. of New-Hampshire also came; and remained to dine— My brother was also of the party— Doctor Waterhouse left us soon after dinner to return to Cambridge— Mr Plumer made some enquiries respecting my controversy with the Boston confederates, in which his father had a particular interest. I lent him the manuscript of my reply, for his own, and his father’s perusal and his own, upon his promise to return it afterwards to me. Mr Connell is here to obtain a power from the claimants for commercial indemnities upon the French Government to compromise their demands. Settlements of this nature have been made with Sweden and Denmark, in both of which Mr Connell had an Agency—and he has been heretofore employed by some of the claimants upon France— My brother’s wife and her niece were here in the Evening— The Ladies took a ride— I was incessantly engaged, with company from 11. of the morning, till past nine at Night, and then afflicted with a severe fit of senile cough, an admonition, which I may no longer overlook— Yet this morning, I planted a row of mingled white Currants, Blackberries, and whortleberries along the Eastern fence— Steeped a pint of Blackberries in a Bottle of New-England Rum; and received a quantity of Lime-seeds and of Cherry Stones for seed from Mr Daniel Greenleaf. Finished reading the 5th. and last book of Cicero’s Treatise de Finibus, and also the Translation of Samuel Parker— I had never read this Book before. The supposed scene of the Dialogue in the fifth Book is at Athens in the very Academy where Plato had held his School— The expositor of the Peripatetic philosophy is Marcus Pupius Piso, Calpurnianus; one of the Orators, Politicians and Orators of the Age, often mentioned in the other writings of Cicero. He takes little part in this Dialogue; only starting occasion a question for Piso to answer— Rather assuming himself the character of a Pyrrhonian, and charging the Peripatetics themselves with inconsistency in their controversy with the Stoics— These five Books contain an excellent Summary of the three great Grecian systems of Philosophy: and a controversial view of two of them the Epicurean and Stoic. The work would have been more perfect, if Cicero had given in the name of Cato, the argument against the Peripatetics— As it is we have both sides of the question concerning the Epicureans and Stoics—and only one for the Academy. The disciples of Epicurus, of Socrates, and of Zeno, were as enthusiastically attached to their Masters, as the followers of Luther and Calvin are in modern times— It is very remarkable that there was no Roman system of Philosophy. The Greeks appear to have exhausted the Powers of the human mind upon the Subject— But probably no one of the Greeks, wrote upon philosophical subjects with so much eloquence as Cicero, excepting Plato.
13. IV. Friday— Lamplight.

Much of this day, as almost the whole of yesterday was wasted in company with visitors. A young man by the name of Irwin from Pittsburg in Pennsylvania brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr. D. Webster, who has been employed as Counsel for the Commonwealth to assist the Attorney and Solicitor General in the Prosecution of the murderers of Joseph White of Salem— The melancholy character of this trial has been aggravated by the sudden death, in the midst of it of the
Chief Justice Isaac Parker. Mr Webster finished yesterday the close of argument against John F. Knapp, who is upon trial, and returned to Boston; but went again to Salem this morning the Jury having reported to the Court last Evening that they could not agree upon their verdict— Irwin is a warm Antimason, and predicts that this Spirit will prevail, and govern the Elections throughout the State of Pennsylvania, and that the Antimasonic Candidate for the Presidency at the next Election will be not Mr Clay, nor Judge M’lean, but Mr Webster— Mr Gay came with much circumlocution to ask of me a Letter of introduction to Mr Clay— Mr Gay is Consul of the United States at Teneriffe, but has been two or three years at home, and is fearful of being removed.— But he is going to visit the Western Country, with the project of making afterwards a Settlement there— I promised him a Letter to Mr Clay. After dinner a Mr Mrs and Miss Henderson of the State of Mississippi called to visit us. Mr Henderson said he had a Letter of introduction to me from Mr Clay; but he had mislaid it— Charles and his wife came out from Medford— We resumed the Catalogue of Books, and just before Sunset, I took a bath and swam from wharf to wharf alone— It was followed by a chilly feeling and rhumatic pains, which gave me an intelligible warning, and which did not wholly pass away with slowly returning warmth— I planted in book-box 3. a row of wood-house Apple seeds— Under Eastern fence, cherry-Stones Pear-seeds and a few wild cherries under South fence, right hand of gate 1. nutmeg Peach and 3. Horse-Plum stones— Read 17 Sections of the first Tusculan, de contemnenda morte— There are five books of these; as there are five de Finibus—and they are in like manner addressed to Marcus Brutus. He gives them as the substance of five Conversations, held on five successive days—with several of his friends at his Tusculan villa; shortly after Brutus had left it. The dialogue is professedly in the Socratic manner— Cicero himself performing the part taken by Socrates in the dialogues of Plato— In this instance, none of the other interlocutors are named, but one of them commences by announcing his opinion upon some controvertible point which Cicero then discusses with him; in Socratic interrogations and remarks— The Editors have divided the dialogue, between Cicero and an Auditor, whose respective parts in the discourse they have designated by the initials A. and M. for Auditor and Marcus. In the first Book the Auditor commences by saying abruptly “I think death is an evil,” which position, Marcus undertakes to disprove—
14. III.30. Saturday.

I am compelled to rise before the dawn of day;—waking between three and four, and thenceforward utterly unable to Sleep again. My cough last Evening and this morning was exceedingly troublesome. Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— After dinner we resumed the Catalogue, and made a further advance towards completing it. I planted a row of the Greenleaf Cherries, with one nutmeg peach and whortleberries at the bottom of the Nursery, and under the Eastern fence—and a row of Pear seeds in the middle box— I collect also a number of small bush seeds to keep dry and plant late in the Autumn, or early next Spring. Mrs Clark and Mrs Brown called to see me this afternoon.
Mrs Clarke is from New-Hampshire and proposes to publish a School book in questions and answers, upon the History of New-England— She had a curiosity to see the Library given by my father to the Town, and I accompanied her to the Office in which it is kept— She also borrowed a couple of books which she sent back this Evening. Commodore and Mrs Morris paid us an afternoon visit— My wife and Mary rode towards Evening; but Charles’s wife was confined the whole day to her chamber, and Robert Buchanan called on Dr Holbrook, who prescribed to him a course of Calomel Pills and a blister— I was obliged to forgo my bath— It is, says Cicero—1st. Tusculan—Section 14—“It is a tacit judgment of Nature herself and the greatest argument in favour of the immortality of Souls, that all men take a deep interest in that which will happen after death— He plants trees says Statius in his Synephebi, for the benefit of another century: for what purpose, if the next century were something to him? The diligent husbandman then shall plant trees, upon which his own eyes will never see a berry? and shall not a great man plant laws, institutions, a Commonwealth?[”]— I have had my share in planting Laws and Institutions, according to the measure of my ability and opportunities— I would willingly have had more— My leisure is now imposed upon me by the will of higher powers, to which I cheerfully submit, and I plant trees for the benefit of the next age, and of which my own eyes will never behold a berry— To raise forest trees requires the concurrence of two generations, and even of my lately planted Nuts seeds and Stones, I may never taste the fruit— Sero arbores quae alteri seculo prosint— Bright Northern Light this Evening.
15. IV. Sunday.

Robert C. Buchanan was confined, by his blister and his pills till the Evening. Mr Whitney of Hingham preached in the morning from Mark 8.36. “For what shall it profit a man, if he shall gain the whole world, and lose his own Soul,” and in the afternoon from 1 Corinthians 2.12. Now we have received, not the Spirit of the world, but the Spirit which is of God. As the afternoon Service was closing it began to rain; and Mr G. W. Beale took Charles and me home in his Carry-all. There was a seasonable and copious Shower. Mr and Mrs Joseph Russell, with Coll. Josiah Quincy paid us an afternoon visit— I finished reading the first Tusculan, upon the contempt of Death, and the argument in it is admirable— Philosophy had undoubtedly great influence upon the conduct of individuals in the age of Cicero, and upon his own particularly— The question whether Death was an Evil, was perhaps an idle one— Nature has implanted in all animated beings a horror of Death, and has made it doubly terrible to man, by the agonies and convulsions which usually precede and attend it; as well as by that interest in the future, which Cicero considers as an argument in favour of the immortality of the Soul. But God has given to Man, both reason and Passions to check, or as Lord Bacon says to mate the fear of Death— Many human beings welcome it.— Many fly to it, and probably there is no aged individual of the human family, but has often desired it. The moment of death is the cessation of suffering, and therefore not in itself painful— The sincere believer in Christianity longs for death, but dares not hasten to it: and in spite of all belief he dreads and shrinks from it. I have read this Dissertation, at the most favourable moment of my life for giving it all its weight—when I have no plausible motive for wishing to live, when every thing that I foresee and believe of futurity, makes Death desirable, and when I have the clearest indications that it is near at hand— I should belie my Conscience should I not acknowledge that the Love of Life, and the horror of dissolution, is as strong in me as it
ever was at any period of my existence, and that I deeply feel the hollowness of the whole argument of Cicero— It is utterly delusive— Yet I do not believe my hold upon life more tenacious than that of most other human beings, especially of those who have great enjoyment of Life— It was a shrewd saying of Sappho, mentioned in a Note to d’Olivet’s translation, that Death was an evil; inasmuch as none of the Gods had ever chosen to die— But although the main argument of this Dissertation is fallacious, the style is always charming. We miss the other side of the question— Shakespear in his Measure for Measure is more candid—
16. IV. Monday.

I have painful Nights, with often interrupted sleep, and rise an hour before day— Lungs loaded with phlegm, and a cough half an hour every morning after rising, followed by another half hour of incessant expectoration— Yet I do not set my house in Order as I ought. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— I deposited a cherry-stone, and 3 Apple-seeds in five of the stands prepared for seedling trees, and planted a row of mixed Apple-seeds at the bottom of the Nursery. The apple-trees from the seeds planted last Summer are now growing, and two of them are now 9 inches high—others have not grown more than two inches— Some four or five— The English Oaks are putting out shoots which have grown from four to five feet this Season; but their growth is irregular, and more lateral than perpendicular. The shoots from the Willow headed down, still grow half an inch a day, and are now 28 inches long— After dinner I took about 30 seeds from two wood-house Apples, and immediately planted a row of them in the middle book-box. Mrs Catherine Codman, and her sister Mrs M’Lean paid us an afternoon visit— I rode to Milton with my two daughters and John, and afterwards with Charles paid an evening visit to Mr Edward Miller. My brother and his wife were there— Their daughter Abigail is unwell—threatened with a consumption. Mrs Miller is also confined; convalescent however from a severe illness. I began the 2d Tusculan; upon the endurance of pain; of which I read 15. Sections and also the translation of the Somnium Scipionis, by D’Olivet, annexed to his first Tusculan— This Scipio was the second Africanus, Son of Lucius Paulus, and therefore called AEmilianus— He was adopted by the Son of the first Africanus, and took Carthage— The Astronomy of the Somnium Scipionis is not more correct than its theory of the immortality of the Soul— It seems they were both taken from the Phaedrus of Plato— Both were approximations to the Truth; and one of the most extraordinary Events in the History of Science and of mankind is that Kepler took the first hint of his Laws of planetary Motion from the Harmony of the Spheres in the dream of Scipio.
17— IV. Tuesday.

The adherence of my Catarrhal Cough, and the Nightly spasms, which are becoming almost habitual, have brought me to serious and anxious reflection, but not yet to action— My time is still trifled away. Disease and pain instead of stimulating to redoubled exertion, sink into dejection, despondency, and idleness. President Quincy was here, this afternoon, and returned to Cambridge— He came to visit Mr and Mrs Russell, who are still at his Son’s house— But they are to return to-morrow to Boston— Mr Quincy told me that degrees would be conferred without difficulty upon my Son John and those of his Classmates who were denied their degrees at the same time with him, if they would request them, the difficulty to granting them spontaneously being, that it would have the appearance of censure upon the Government of the University at that time— The Ladies rode this afternoon and I was engaged with Charles at the old Office in continuing to make the Catalogue of my books.
The time of ripening of much fruit is now coming on from day to day; and as a great proportion of the seeds will not bear keeping dry a single day, I am continually planting them, with the intention of stocking the half of my Nursery yet disengaged with seedling fruit-trees to come up next Spring or Summer. Serit arbores quae alteri seculo prosint; is my apology to myself for the Time, I employ upon this subject— I also propose it as a mode of exercise for health; though it has not hitherto answered that expectation— I have no substitute for it—and the disposition to make experiments to ascertain what seed will come up and what is the relation between the seed, and the plant that springs from it leads me to much hobby horsical trifling— Let this pass for my general confession, if it may not serve for my justification— Isaac Farrar, gathered this day the Woodhouse Apples to take to Boston Market— I took a peck of them myself, for seed; but they are not ripe, and should have remained on the tree till about the first of September— Gathered the Jargonelle Pears on the small tree—not quite ripe— The tree and fruit in decay— Picked up wind-fallen Sugar Pears, and planted a row of the seeds in the middle box— A row of sweeting Apple seeds with one nutmeg Peach stone, and one R. D. Horse Plum Stone, under Eastern fence— Rufus Davis brought yesterday some horse plums of which I took 3. Pints, six dozen, for seed— But they are not ripe— I finished reading the 2d. Tusculan; upon bearing pain—and began the third; upon Affliction— The second is more for practical use than the first—instructive; fortifying and consolatory. It is particularly adapted to my circumstances, and ought to be profitable to me— There are several considerable extracts from Greek Poets: Sophocles, AEschylus and Homer, translated by Cicero into Latin verse, of which he says he made much practice— The verse is very good; and the Spirit of them is well preserved in the French translations of them given by D’Olivet.
18. IV:15 Wednesday— Charles 23.

Planted the Limeseeds given me by Daniel Greenleaf, in a heap at the bottom of the Nursery. A row of wild Cherries in Book box 3— That fruit is now ripening— And I deposited Cores of the sugar pear, also now ripening, under the five stands, where I propose to raise Standard fruit trees— By planting in each a variety; and of several fruits I wish to ensure a standard of some fruit in each stand. If many fail there will be multiplied chances for one to succeed in each place— It was my Son Charles’s birth-day, and may this occasion be allowed me for supplicating a blessing upon his Life!— We continued the Catalogue after dinner.— And I walked over the Hill in front of the house— Gathered a handfull of Wild Cherries, and one of Limeseeds from the Tree on the Hancock lot— They are far fresher than any of those given me by Daniel Greenleaf and have living kernels within them; but they float in water and I think will never vegetate— The Evening was merely cool and my pains returned with more of menace than of severity— I sought for them in bed as the Clock rung nine— I this day finished the reading of the Bible, which I began about the first of May last year— This reading has not been so profitable to me as it ought to have been— Among the decays of Age, which I cannot dissemble to myself is a falling off in the discipline of the mind. The operation of the mind in reading should be like that of the leech upon the body: but the leech sometimes wanders over the veins, without taking hold of any one, and so it is in the dissipation of Spirits, which comes on with the lassitude of years— In my frequent perusals of the Bible heretofore, I have perhaps gathered all of the important religious and moral instruction that I am capable of receiving from it; and as for biblical criticism or controversy, the remnant of
my days if devoted exclusively to these studies, would leave me a mere smatterer in them. The attempt therefore would be worse than useless, and I purposely abstain from it. In reflecting upon the Time which I still devote to reading, and in meeting the question, what purpose it answers, I find that the object of reading is different at different periods of life. In Youth it is for instruction; for the acquisition of knowledge and the practical improvement of it. In age, it is for pleasure and pastime. The morning hours which I now devote—one to the Bible, and two to Cicero, bear no fruits— I fear they add little to my knowledge, and nothing to my capacity to do good— They are hours of high enjoyment—but this is not the end of life— If I could hope for a protracted term of possible activity it would become an indispensable duty to alter this arrangement— To commence the day with action, and to postpone speculation and reading, at least until after breakfast— And so if I recover health and efficient Resolution, I will do.
19. IV. Thursday. Boston— Meeting— Overseers of Harvard University.

I saw the dog star this morning—half an hour risen at a quarter past four O’Clock. It is therefore certain that with a clear sky, he might have been seen at least ten days earlier: and if the dog days have any meaning, they terminate in this Latitude about the ninth or tenth of August. I have been upon the watch to see him rise from the first of this month, at which time he must have risen with the Sun— Eight days later gives him time to emerge. I went to Boston with my Sons John and Charles, and Lieutt. Buchanan— Visited John Welles and I. P. Davis, but they were out— Edward Cruft with whom and his Son William I went to see an Anaconda, from Java, and two Boa Constrictors from Sumatra—a small Alligator, and a Harlequin or diamond Snake— None of these Serpents was venomous. And the Anaconda, and the two Boas having been fed yesterday each with a rabbit, they were this day very sluggish; coiled and intertwined with each other and lying nearly torpid in their cages the keeper himself could rouse them to very little action.— The Anaconda, the largest of the three was about 14 feet long—his body about the size of a Man’s thigh, about the centre swolen with the whole rabbet upon which he had feasted yesterday, as were the two others. Their principal movement was frequently thrusting out a thready and forked tongue— There was much resemblance between them; and their colours were disgustingly beautiful— They were perfectly tame and gentle, and their keeper handled them at his pleasure. I called upon Judge Davis and sat an hour with him conversing upon Railways, City Government, theological controversy, Professor Stuart, and Dr Channing— We went together to the Meeting of the Overseers of Harvard University, at the Council Chamber— At 1/2 past twelve O’Clock the Lieutenant Governor Winthrop took the Chair— President Quincy proposed several new By-Laws or Ordinances, which had been adopted by the Corporation; tending to the new tension of discipline; two or three of which were adopted without opposition. There was one, to authorize the President, at the written request of Parents to license the attendance of individual Students at the theatre in Boston, which James T. Austin opposed. He gave a horrible description of the licentiousness in the region of the Tremont Theatre, and protested against any colour of sanction to be given for attendance by any Student at the Theatre, under any circumstances whatever— The President said this Picture was entirely new to him and that he would not press the ordinance further— Mr Pearce the Minister of Brookline, seconded the views of Mr Austin, and said that the only graduate of several years, at Cambridge for several years, had narrowly escaped total ruin, by seduction at the Theatre to an infamous
marriage— The subject was postponed and referred to a Committee of 3. Judge Davis, J. T. Austin and Savage, to report— Several honorary degrees were proposed; one of a medical doctorate to a person resident at Quebec; which was opposed by Dr Spooner. There was a rule that there should be thirty days interval between the proposition to the Overseers of these honorary degrees and their confirmation— There was a question made whether this rule should be suspended which passed in the negative. The Meeting was adjourned before two O’Clock to commencement Morning— About twenty Members in attendance, a majority of whom were Boston Clergymen. I returned to Charles’s office; where Lieutenant Buchanan soon joined us having paid his visit to fort Independence, and we returned to Quincy to dine— Unfortunately unhorsed a man at the Cross street at the bottom of the Mall, by running the Pole of the carriage upon him— He was hurt, but able to remount his horse, though already too much steeped in Spirit— Visited the garden after dinner. Planted Plum-stones, Pear Cores, and the Lime Seeds I had gathered the Evening before last— Began reading the Bible again, and finished the third Tusculan, upon Affliction— I read the first chapter of Genesis, in the Greek Septuagint; but the type is too small for my eye sight.
20. IV. Friday.

Sirius was about fifteen minutes above the horizon when I rose at four this morning, and I saw him still at 4:40 about half an hour before the Sun rose— From the difficulty of reading the type of my copy of the Septuagint Bible, I have reverted to the English, three chapters a day, with two or three pages of the illustrations added to the English Translation of Calmet, which are altogether different from the Dissertations of Calmet himself. Began the 4th. Tusculan, upon the Passions—of which I read 13 Sections, and afterwards the translation of the same by D’Olivet— The translation of the third is by Bouhier, who like almost all French Translators takes inexcusable Liberties with his original—omitting large passages, and particularly the whole of the fourth and fifth Sections— They contain a curious philological disquisition upon the terms used in the Greek and Latin Languages to designate the Passions— He seems perplexed with the Greek word πάθη which he says in Latin signifies morbus—but he prefers to translate it perturbationes. He does not use the word Passio nor was it then a word known to the Latin Language. The earliest authority in Gesner’s Thesaurus for the term Passio, for Passions, is Firmicus, a Christian writer of the fourth Century— The observation of the Passions presupposes a distinction between body and Soul; and the Classification of the Passions was naturally incidental, to the theory that the Seat of the Passions is not in the body— These Speculations are all Greek, and almost all from Socrates— The word aegritudo, seems to import nothing but sickness, and that perhaps is the reason why in this Tusculan Cicero states the Greek term πάθη to be also equivalent to sickness— But the subject discussed is affliction, and the doctrine taught is that the wise man, must not be accessible to it, or rather that he must encounter and subdue it. There are many admirable observations upon it, and if read and meditated upon in youth this philosophy must contribute to form habits of virtue and sources of enjoyment— Mr Whitney the Minister of the Parish, and his second Son, Frederic Augustus who is at the University called upon us this morning; and Mrs Tufts of Weymouth with her daughter Mercy and Louisa C Smith this afternoon— By abstemious diet I was able to write this afternoon and answered the Letters of César Moreau, and of
George D. Prentice, who applies to me to assist him in writing the life of Mr Clay: Charles and his wife went to Boston, but returned to dinner— Towards Evening, I walked to my brother’s, where I found his Son John Quincy, arrived this afternoon from the Academy at Exeter. They have a vacation of three weeks— My brother’s daughter Abigail has been several days ill, confined to her bed— Mr E. Miller and Dr Woodward came in while I was there— Robert C. Buchanan, who had rode with the Ladies, followed me to my brother’s, and walked home with me. I planted a row of R. D. Plums. 3. a Stone, and Appleseeds at the bottom of the Nursery. All the Shellbark trees in the Summer house garden, but one, have died.
21. IV:15. Saturday.

Charles and Lieutenant Buchanan went to Nahant and returned about nine this Evening— I attempted to change the order of my daily occupations, and after the reading of the Bible to write in this diary but did not finish the record of yesterday before breakfast. I planted 12 whole R. D. horse Plums, in a Row under the Eastern fence placing a small Index Stake at one end and a marked Stone which I covered with the Earth at the other; dropping cores of Pears with the seeds in them in the intervals between the Plums— In the Garden I put a whole plum not R. D. under five of the stands. Mr Bailey came and introduced to me a young man named Lovering of Medway, who is about finishing the study of the Law, and has the intention of going to settle at Cincinnati, in the State of Ohio. He seemed to be concerned at the accounts of the recent Elections in Kentucky which have terminated unfavourably to Mr Clay— To close the afternoon I rambled over the hill opposite my house, for exercise—taking note of plants and trees as I went— The wild Cherries are riper on the young than on old Trees— I mark them as successively ripe, from 15. August to 15 September— I gathered a handful of them for seed and for steeping in New-England Rum. The trees bear plentifully this year. So do the Walnuts, both Pignut and Shellbark; of which there are upwards of thirty trees on these Hills—all but three or four from Pignuts. The dewberry, or Low Blackberry, and high Blackberry vines cover much of the ground; but bear little fruit, and are totally neglected. The wild Cherry; the Shellbark and Pignut Hickories and the Blackberries are indigenous Plants of this Country, and it is remarkable that they are never cultivated— Yet the trees are among the most useful plants that earth produces; the fruit and the wood of both being very valuable— The principal objection to the Cherry tree is that it harbours Caterpillars; an evil to be remedied by attention and Industry. The Caterpillars annoy the Hickory also and I strip’d off a Nest of them from one of my trees— I found only one Oak—a very fine, large Black Oak, but upon which there was not an Acorn to be seen— I met several other trees and shrubs which I did not know, and one or two grape-vines— The fertility of Nature in all her reigns, baffles human curiosity, and I never can take a walk for observation or musing, but I meet multitudes of Plants, Insects and birds, the names, properties, and uses of which equally convict me of my ignorance— Ignorance invincible, for the books upon natural history give no account of the greater part of these productions, and the farmers who spend their lives among them know less of them than I do— I read 13. Sections of the fourth Tusculan, Original and D’Olivet’s French Translation— The day’s Newspapers announce that the Jury on the second trial of John Francis Knapp, yesterday convicted him of the murder of Joseph White.
22. IV:15. Sunday.

Walk with Charles in the Garden Nursery— Struck with the growth of English Oaks— Stems of six or seven feet long this Season; and yet growing— The other Oaks have ceased growing these Six or Seven weeks. I proposed to Charles, to select a spot on one of the farms for an Orchard— Heard Mr P. Whitney, who closed the Series of his discourses upon the difficult passages in the New Testament, by a review of the Epistles of John and of Jude— He said he should not remark upon the Book of Revelations, because it was a sublime prophesy of Events, many of which were not yet fulfilled— The text of his afternoon Sermon was from Acts 17.30. “And the times of this ignorance God winked at, but now commandeth all men every where to repent: 31. Because he hath appointed a day in the which he will judge the world in righteousness, by that man whom he hath ordained: whereof he hath given assurance unto all men, in that he hath raised him from the dead.[”] Mr Whitney was duly impressed with the awfulness of the day of Judgment, thus explicitly declared to have been appointed and he maintained his own peculiar sectarian opinions, by the authority here equally explicit that the world will be judged by a Man— He also cited all the other passages of the New Testament, in which Jesus Christ is expressly denominated a man— There are other passages as unequivocal in which he is acknowledged as God— The Trinitarian doctrine of the double nature of Christ, solves these difficulties; nor is there in it any thing discordant or unintelligible to those who believe in the double nature of Man—consisting of a perishable body, and an immortal Soul— Louisa C. Smith and my brother’s two Sons, Isaac and John dined with us, and in the Evening with Charles and his wife I visited Coll. Quincy and saw his infant son, whom they call Josiah the fifth— I finished reading the fourth Tusculan, upon the Government of the Passions.

23. IV:30. Monday— Heavy Rain and thunder shower in the Night— Charles goes to Boston at 8 in the Morning, and returns between 2 and 3. to dine— I planted 12 whole wild Cherries next the Row of R. D. Plums, under the East fence, and a cross row of six in the middle book box— Also 2. Nutmeg Peach Stones between the book boxes— Gathered a small basket of Horse-Plums, and a like quantity of Catherine Pears—also sweeting Apples. The Sugar Pears fall about a bushel a day from the Tree— I plant pear Cores and apple seeds between the whole wild Cherries— Opened a box of Port wine from Washington—40 Bottles entire and 6 broken— Inspected the Cellars and gave directions for keeping them in order— After dinner I went with Charles to one of my Railway lots to see if there was any Oak or walnut wood there which would now be fit for cutting down, for fuel: the stock I had provided for last Autumn beginning to run low. We found the wood all too small— We went to the top of the Tower built by Coll. Perkins at the ledge. It has 58 steps within. The Stone cutters are now at work in the rear of it— The atmosphere was beclouded and hazy which abridged the beautiful Prospect from the Tower— I took Salmon Farrar with me, and brought home 2 Clusters of ripe Pokeberries, and several twigs of native Bass-wood, covered with seeds now ripening, which I suppose more likely to vegetate than those of the exotic Lime-tree— They have fresh and apparently sound kernels in them, but they still float in water, which renders their germinating faculty doubtful— I read fourteen Sections of the 5th. Tusculan and Bouhier’s Translation.
The purpose of the fourth Tusculan is to prove that the wise man is not affected by any of the Passions— The subject follows in regular order, after the consideration of Death, Pain, and affliction—and the whole is connected with the Books de Finibus— In the study of Self-knowledge, the first enquiry naturally was for the supreme good; and next to that how to guard against the ills of Life— The Epicureans and Stoics rushed into the two extremes—one centering all human happiness in sensual enjoyment. The other excluding the body altogether— But it was an admirable conclusion to arrive at that the Supreme good consisted in virtue; and it will remain for ever true, that the highest happiness consists in the practice of virtue— Bodily pain, and perturbation of mind are however evils— The classification of the Passions in this Treatise, is somewhat imperfect— The term aegritudo is not exactly rendered by affliction—from its derivation it imports sickness, and in the third Tusculan is used for the sickness of the heart caused by affliction in general. In the fourth it is classed with Fear among the painful perturbations; while Cupidity or Lust, and excessive Joy are considered as the perturbations of Pleasure. There are passages where he seems disposed to confine the perturbations to four as counterparts to the Cardinal Virtues; but at other places he includes envy, malice, Anger, Pity, and Love among the Passions— There is much of the Orator in his discourse upon Love— His general argument is that opinion is the foundation of all the Passions. That they are therefore voluntary, and ought to be always under the controul of that Will— That the controuler of them is Virtue, and that the wise mans happiness consists in having them under complete controul—
24. IV:30. Tuesday.

Charles and his wife went to Boston. John and Lieutt. Buchanan to Dedham on a visit to Mr and Mrs Barrell, recently removed from Washington, and settled there. They all returned home to dine. My two wards, Ward N. Boylston, and Thomas Boylston came to visit me; being now in vacation from their School at Leicester. I made enquiry as to the state of their Studies— Ward is fourteen years of age, and may enter at Cambridge next year. Thomas is ten, and has not begun to learn Latin— I asked him when he expected to begin— He said he did not know— I examined Ward in construeing a passage in Cicero’s Oration for Archias and in one against Catiline. I had not time to examine Thomas, their Grandmother having directed them to return to dine at Roxbury— While they were here Mr William Beach Laurence, who was sometime Charge d’Affaires of the United States at London paid me a visit— He was appointed Secretary to Mr Gallatin, and was Chargé d’Affaires in the interval between him and James Barbour. There was some ignorant and malicious chicanery made about the settlement of his Accounts, after his return from England, and an Act of Congress passed at the last Session, to authorize the Settlement of them, as they should have been settled without it— He says they are settled at last. This has been the summit of President Jackson’s Statesmanship— To snatch at the Letter of a Statute, which in former Administrations had been construed according to its intention—to forbid the continuance of the former construction, as contrary to Law; so as to give himself the appearance of a reformer; and then get a special act of Congress to remove the senseless obstacle raised by himself— Laurence spoke of Politics European and American. He says that the present king of England, when Mr Gallatin was presented to him asked him, if the People in America spoke English as he did; and whether they wrote English
as he spoke it. Laurence mentioned it as a sample of William the fourth’s sense and breeding. He said also that he had lately made a tour in the western Country, and had visited Mr Clay at Lexington: found him in fine health and Spirits; expecting that the new Elections in Kentucky would give an overwhelming majority in his favour, and that he would be nominated by the ensuing Legislature as a Candidate for the Presidency in opposition to the re-election of General Jackson— The result of the Elections has been a great disappointment— The latest accounts however being more favourable than those which preceded— He said it was probable the Anti-masonic interest would go for Mr Clay; a Letter having been received from Mr Clark, stating that Mr Clay had for many years withdrawn from attendance at the Lodges— But this Countercheck in the Kentucky Elections, had an inauspicious effect upon his prospects— This afternoon a Mr Reeve from Hartford came with a subscription paper for the proposed biography of Mr Clay by G. D. Prentice— I rode with my wife and Mary this Evening—first to Mount Wollaston to see Alpheus Spear, but he was absent from home, not to return for a week— Thence we went round by Gulliver’s Brook— A slight accident made us alight just as we were reaching home— In the Nursery I planted 12. Plumstones with Pear Cores and seeds and 12 Wild cherries under the Eastern fence; and in the Garden a row of Catherine Pear seeds and Cores across the Middle Book Box—with stakes marked Wild Cherries and Catherine Pears.
25. IV— Wednesday—

Commencement day— My Son Charles and Lieutt. Buchanan went to Cambridge, and attended the performances— The August Gale of departing Summer came on, but with little Rain— I planted a Row of mixed Plum Stones, Pear Cores and Seeds, Apple-seeds, steeped Currants, Wild Cherries, and Bass wood seeds, at the bottom of the Nursery— Mr Sega and Mr Bonfils came while we were at dinner— Sega has published a pamphlet upon duelling; which having met with approbation, he proposes to expand in a second Edition into a volume, for which he is soliciting Subscriptions— At the Office, I was consulting the Encyclopaedia, for the Article Woodchuck; which is not there— Nor in any of the Dictionaries we possess— Farrar shot one yesterday, which we had this day in a pye at dinner— It passed at first for an Opossum; but upon question made we examined the Dictionaries and Buffon— In the last we found the Opossum, which he calls the Sarigue; but no woodchuck— While looking for the Encyclopaedia, I found two papers one of Willow Oak and one of Water Oak Acorns, given me I believe last Summer, by Mr Charles Harrod of New-Orleans, but which I then neglected, and had forgotten— They are now in all probability good for nothing; though a few of the willow, and most of the Water Oak Acorns still sink in Water. Had I planted them last Autumn they would no doubt have come up. Charles and Robert returned about nine this Evening. I finished reading the fifth and last of the Tusculan questions or disputations, and the Translation of Bouhier. It forms the conclusion, of the ten books and is devoted to prove that Virtue alone is sufficient for the consummate happiness of man. A glorious theme, well suited to the display of the Genius of Cicero— Brutus to whom both these works were addressed, and at whose instigation they were written had come to the same conclusion in his Treatise
de Virtute, which is lost— It is no small demonstration of the excellence of those principles professed by the Stoic and Academic philosophers, that the men who professed them were the most virtuous men of their age, and among the most virtuous men of any age. The Epicurean Statesmen were corrupt and vicious men— The Stoics and Academics could not be so without flying in the face of their principles abeunt studia in mores. Cato and Brutus were Stoics— Cicero adopted the Stoic doctrine that happiness consists in virtue— Caesar and Cassius were Epicureans— The Christian system of morals sums up the whole duty of man in piety and benevolence undoubtedly a doctrine superior to that of the Greek Philosophers. It makes the end of human existence the performance of duty— The Greek philosophy made enjoyment the end of existence— The Greek system is speculative, the Christian is preceptive. I would fain pursue this parallel but have not now time—
26. IV. Thursday.

This was the day of the Declamations at Cambridge for the Boylston prizes, and I had received an invitation from President Quincy to attend them, which I had inclined to accept but the storm of yesterday continued and increased to a Tempest, with floods of rain; which confined us all to the house, and almost overflowed with it with leakage— Before the rain came on I visited my garden and Nursery— Planted 1. Willow and 1. Water Oak in each of four boxes— A row of Water and Willow Oaks across the middle wood-box; and a row of Water Oak Acorns, mixed with Plum-Stones, Pear Cores, wild cherries, Bass wood seeds, and Appleseeds straight South from the Boxes— I was obliged to take refuge in the house from the Rain. Plums gathered from the trees in front of the house— Ripe— Squash and Catherine Pears, falling ripe— Spent the afternoon in making the Catalogue of my German Books; which we did not finish— Read 12 Sections of the Lucullus, or Academics of Cicero— An incomplete work of which the Letters to Atticus 16. and 19 of the 13th. Book, give some information. It is an exposition of the Academic system of Philosophy founded by Socrates, and principally taught by Plato. Cicero first wrote his Treatise in two books, one entitled Catulus and the other Lucullus. This second Book is the one yet extant, and which I am reading— On reflection he changed the names of the interlocutors from Lucullus, Hortensius and Catulus, who were little versed in these Speculations to Cato and Brutus. But receiving a Letter from Atticus advising him to address some Treatise of his to Varro, he immediately took the hint, wrote the work over again in four Books, and made Varro and Atticus the interlocutors, with himself. Of this second work, only a part of the first book has escaped the ravages of time so that what we have is the second Book of the first Edition, and a part of the first Book of the second. In both Cicero speaks as the defender of the Academic philosophy— The objection urged against which was, the principle of the uncertainty of human knowledge.
27. V. Friday.

The storm gradually abated during the Night, but the rain continued, this morning till near our breakfast time— The sky cleared up slowly through the day, and the weather again became warm— My wife in the wet and cold weather has been threatened with a return of the Erisypelas— On visiting after breakfast this morning my Garden and Nursery, I found the Apples and Pears blown from the Trees, all the ripe and bushels of the green— Many unripe peaches, and a few of the Shellbark Walnuts. Many of my young trees were partially damaged; and the roots especially of the young peach trees laid bare. I suspended plantation for this day, but hoed up some of the ground. After dinner I finished with Charles the Catalogue of my German Books. Read 12. Sections of the Lucullus, and the Letters
to Varro, relating to the Academic Books— Rode with Charles to Mount Wollaston farm, to look for a place upon which to set out an Orchard— But Alpheus Spear has not yet got home— We rode down to the beach which is covered with Seaweed from the storm; with flocks of aquatic birds and swarms of mosquitos— I examined a few of the Oak trees black and white, and found they were bearing Acorns. After returning home, I walked with Robert C Buchanan to my brother’s. His daughter Abigail is convalescent. Mr John Marston visited me this afternoon with Mr Andrews from Louisiana.
28. III.45. Saturday.

I planted a row of Pear Cores, Apple seeds, Bass wood seeds, steeped Currants wild Cherries, and Water Oak Acorns, opposite the young fence— Apple tree at the division between the tree ground, and the Leghorn Wheat of Thayer. To lose as little ground as possible I plant the seeds at different depths some four or five inches, and some not more than two inches deep— Mr Read a mender of Clocks was here, and cleaned the Old Clock made by Willard at Lexington for my father and now about 60 years old— It took him the whole morning and he dined with us— General Dearborn sent his Son William, with his Cock and Hen of the Norman breed, which he has given me— This is the breed of the Poule de Caux, with his tufted head— Some years since, dining with General Dearborn of this breed of fowls of which in France they make the Poulardes, and spoke of them as a breed well worth importing into this Country— He did accordingly import two Cocks and four hens: kept one Cock and one hen himself, and sent here, the winter before last, while my brother yet lived here, a Cock and three hens— But they had diseases incident to dunghill fowls, perhaps contracted on the voyage from France; and a merciless War was waged upon the Cock, by the Cocks of other breeds then upon the farm— When I came here last Summer, the Cock and three hens, two black and one speckled were here; but there was no one here able to pay the attention necessary to propagate the breed— One of the Black Hens brooded upon a Nest of 12 eggs, not her own, but of the common breed— These she hatched and brought up; and when I left here last December nine of them were fowls nearly full grown and in perfect health— The speckled Hen, brooded for a time upon a Nest of seventeen eggs of the right kind, made for her by John Thomas; but she was a bad Hen, and ate up her own eggs— The old cock was nearly or quite blind from his battles— When I returned here last June, the Cock and one of the black Hens were gone— Isaac Farrar told me they disappeared last Winter, one Night with several of his own fowls— He knew not what had become of them— There remained only one of the black Hens and the Speckle, which was diseased— Mrs Pitts and Mrs Kirke understand the management of fowls, and the same black hen which raised last year a spurious brood, was brought to set this year on a nest of 19 eggs of which she hatched on the last of July, only five, one of these died, and she has now four chickens, four weeks old, three of which are black, as herself and one dark brown— They are of the true breed, and the tuft is just beginning to shew itself on the top of the head— They are the finest breed of the dunghill fowls for the table and for the eggs—both being nearly double the size of the common fowls of this Country— General Dearborn has been still less successful with his fowls than we with ours, and as I enquired of him several times how they were, the last time he was here he said he would send me his cock and hen, that they might be all together, and thus a better chance of preserving the breed— The Cock is younger than the one I had before; and better conditioned; but the hen is a speckle, and Mrs Pitts found on examination that both of them had the pip— They were no sooner set down in the Clothes-line yard than the Cock was furiously attacked by a young Cock of my last years brood, who has had the rule, the present Season, till now, and in the course of three hours they had three pitched battles: the yearling Cock, though much smaller, being of a more martial breed than the Norman—till at last the speckled hen interfered, and the young cock retired— Abigail S. Adams called here with Ann Harrod who is
going immediately to Haverhill—and thence in a fortnight to New-Orleans. Mr and Mrs Barrell, late of Washington, but recently settled at Dedham paid us a morning visit— At 5 this afternoon Lieutenant Robert C. Buchanan who has spent eight weeks of his furlough here, left us: my Son John went with him to Dedham; whence he goes to-morrow to New-London— There he expects to find his Sister Mrs Wade— He will shortly go on to Washington— John returned this Evening from Dedham— I rode this afternoon with my two daughters over Milton Hill into Dorchester, returning over an upper bridge across Neponset stream— My brother was part of the Evening here.
29. III.45. Sunday.

My wife has a severe return of Erisypelas, and is confined to her chamber—with face and eye much inflamed— Walking with Charles in my Nursery I found a plant just up; under the fence at the South-east Corner— I think a bean, cast in with the Cherries two Months since— Heard Mr Hedge of West-Cambridge this morning from Acts 26.9. “I verily thought with myself, that I ought to do many things contrary to the name of Jesus of Nazareth,” and in the afternoon from Acts 17.21. “For all the Athenians, and strangers which were there spent their time in nothing else, but either to tell or to hear some new thing.” The first of these Sermons was upon the dangerous and pernicious character of consciencious error, and the second was upon the evil consequences of indulging the love of novelty and the disposition to excitement—both ingenious and well written— In the first there was a rapid sketch of the Character of St. Paul, and in the second of the Athenian People, indicating an inquisitive and meditative mind— The texts were well selected to illustrate moral principles of no trivial importance; and the views of the preacher were original and interesting. His style is polished and ornamental— He was listened to with universal attention. He dined with us— He is a Son of the Professor of moral philosophy and was a Classmate of my Son Charles. I bathed with Charles at 5 this afternoon, but the tide was still so low that we were obliged to go in at the beach instead of the wharf— I had after it a troublesome pain in the left side— Met Alpheus Spear as we were returning home— Bespoke some loads of wood of him; and spoke of choosing a spot upon the farm to set out an Orchard— Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf were here in the Evening— He says that the scions of stone fruit to be grafted should be cut in February; and those of Apples and Pears in March—and that the grafting should in both cases be done about a month afterwards— I finished reading the Lucullus; being the second Book of the first work of Cicero upon the Academic philosophy. It is a dialogue supposed to have been held at the villa of Hortensius at Bauli, with Lucullus and Catulus, at whose house there had been another the preceding day— That was the first Book of the first Treatise and is lost— This consists of a narrative by Lucullus of a philosophical argument between Antiochus and Philo two of the Greek Philosophers, upon the total uncertainty of human knowledge, which was maintained by Philo and contested by Antiochus, and which constituted the difference between the old and the new Academy— Lucullus after stating the whole reasoning of Antiochus to prove the certainty of human knowledge declares his assent to that opinion; and Catulus calls upon Cicero for his defence of the opposite doctrine, which he accordingly gives, and shews that it was the original doctrine of Socrates the founder of the School, and that it was essential to their system of teaching, which affirmed nothing as
positive, and sought knowledge from every source, doubting, and enquiring, and avowing the knowledge of nothing but its own ignorance—
30. III.30. Monday.

My bath of last Evening was succeeded by pains in my left side all night, and increased Catarrh this Morning— Planted a Row of Willow Oak Acorns, staked with that name, at the bottom of the Nursery and as it is extremely doubtful whether any of them will ever come up, I intermixed with them, Water-Oak Acorns Pear Cores, Apple-seeds, Bass wood seeds, and steeped Currants— At different depths in the same row. I received a morning visit from Mr Poinsett who introduced to me Mr Sevalla, Governor of the State of Mexico, but now in exile— This gentleman manifested a strong feeling for the condition of his Country, and an anxious desire for the establishment in it of a system of free and orderly Government—but he appeared to entertain better wishes than hopes. Poinsett said he had come away from South-Carolina, because it was in every respect too hot for him— The People of that State have been wrought up into a state of frenzy against the Tariff, and there is a party among them avowing the determination to nullify the Law by the authority of the State. For this paroxysm of popular rage, there is no cause, but it verifies an observation of Lord Bacon that most popular tumults and dissensions arise without adequate cause. Poinsett says that Calhoun is at the bottom of it all; and is now the instigator of the most violent measures— He further said that he himself had consented to be a candidate for the State Legislature— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I rode towards Evening with my daughters to Braintree— Gathered Plums in the Line yard—late. Most of them decayed on the tree— Those gathered between the 20th. and 25th. have ripened well in the house— I read the fragment of the first Book of the Academics of the second Edition which remains—probably not more than a fourth part of the Book— The 8th.
