Letter of the 9th Book of the familiar Epistles, or the 14th of the 11th. book of Melmoth’s Translation is that with which Cicero addressed his four Books of Academics to Varro— The interlocutors are Cicero, Varro and Atticus—at the Cuman Villa of Varro, the discussion is upon the comparative merits of the old or Plato’s Academy, and the new, founded by Arcesilas— The account of them is given by Varro in the remaining fragment; but it is broken off at the 12th. Section. In the books that are lost Cicero maintained the entire uncertainty of human knowledge. He had in these Treatises, set forth his own preference for the old Academy, and his reasons for it— The loss of them has left imperfect that complete and connected system of Grecian moral philosophy, composed by Cicero in the last years of his life, after the usurpation of Caesar, had discarded him from all active co-operation in public affairs.
31. IV. Tuesday.

I planted at the bottom of the Nursery a Row of 12 whole Woodhouse Apples— Horse Plums and Bell and Catherine Pears, with a marked stake, and over them strewed a Row of Water-Oak Acorns and year-steeped huckleberries— John Kirke began the bottling of the Pipe of Madeira Wine. Two Musk Melons ripe at the bottom of the Nursery; gathered them— After dinner I strolled over the Hill to the old Trask garden spot and marked the condition of the trees— There are about forty Hickory Trees among which five or six Shellbarks well laden with fruit— One very fine and large black Oak, and one or two smaller ones; but none bearing Acorns— One Ash with quantities of its seed pods hanging upon it, not yet ripe a considerable growth of Cedars, and of the Juniper three or four Elms, and as many old Pear Trees— A part of the ground is growing over to wood. The wild Cherries on the old Tree
are not yet ripe— Returning home, I spoke to Isaac Farrar of the Shellbark Nuts which he did not know were there— He said the boys stole them all—he never had had the benefit of any part of the fruit on that portion of the farm— But he said if they could be gathered at all it must be immediately after the first frost— Abigail S. Adams dined with us; and John went with her after dinner, and visited Mrs Barrell at Dedham— They returned in the Evening. Mr Beale was here, and notified me that the annual meeting of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge would be next Tuesday at Squantum; and invited me to the dinner at 2. O’Clock. My wife was again able to leave her chamber— I began reading Cicero de Natura Deorum and also the Translation of D’Olivet— And I am reading also the last number of the Library of entertaining knowledge—upon Insect Transformations.

Day. Differs very little from that of the last Month; but I have been obliged to give up almost entirely my Seawater baths—the last two having produced unequivocal bad effects upon my Catarrhal cough— But this has abridged my daily exercise by one hour, and made it necessary to seek a substitute, which I have found in my garden, and especially in the Nursery of trees. The fancy for planting alteri seculo, for the next century has become a marotte; and the partial success I have had stimulates me to further experiments— I have planted seeds or Stones of fruit trees almost every day of this month; and the digging and planting have exercised me about 2 hours every morning— I propose so far as I may obtain supplies of seeds, Stones and nuts to continue this planting through the next Month, and part of October. A more extensive planting must be postponed at least until the next year, which if I should not see, it will but add one more to the disappointments of human designs— My purposes even of exercise, and amusement look to futurity; but whether a futurity on earth is reserved for me or mine is in the dispensation of a higher power— I have in this month finished and recommenced the reading of the Bible; and still read three or four pages of the illustrations of the English Translation of Calmet— And after finishing the Orations of Cicero I am now in the midst of his philosophical works— But I write nothing, save the trash of this Diary, and a very few short, indispensable and insignificant Letters—
